description: Decimal concatenation of n, n+1, and n+2.
comments: The portion of the sequence with all three numbers having d digits - i.e., n in 10^(d-1)..10^d-3 - is in arithmetic sequence: a(n) = (10^(2*d)+10^d+1)*n + (10^d+2). - Franklin T. Adams-Watters, Oct 07 2011All terms are divisible by 3. Every third term starting with a(2) is divisible by 9. - _Alonso del Arte_, May 27 2013
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
example: a(8) = 8910 since the three consecutive numbers starting with 8 are 8, 9, 10, and these concatenate to 8910. (This is the first term that differs from A193431).
mathematica: concat3Nums[n_] := FromDigits@ Flatten@ IntegerDigits[{n, n + 1, n + 2}]; Array[concat3Nums, 25] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_ *)
author: mag(AT)laurel.salles.entpe.fr
